title: Reduced Tillage Systems for Organic Vegetable Production

tasks.task: Conducting agricultural research on reduced tillage systems for organic vegetable production
subtasks: Seed cover crops (rye and vetch) in the previous fall
Apply mechanical termination using a roller crimper when cover crops reach flowering stage
Subdivide whole plot treatments into two subplots for nitrogen fertilization strategies
Apply full or partial nitrogen fertilizer pre-plant and manage fertigation schedule
Monitor nitrate leaching using lysimeters
Compare yields between no-till, strip-till, and conventional till systems

tasks.task: Evaluating cover crop termination methods
subtasks: Using a roller crimper (INJ model) to terminate cover crops
Adjusting equipment (Hineker 6000 strip tiller) for effective cover crop residue management

tasks.task: Implementing strip-till for weed control and fertilizer application
subtasks: Utilizing a strip tiller for row cleaning, cutting residue, subsoiling, fertilizer placement, and clod breaking
Managing cover crop residue in rows during the growing season

tasks.task: Managing organic vegetable crops in no-till plots
subtasks: Maintaining mulch layer for weed suppression
Monitoring and controlling inter-row weeds without mechanical cultivation

tasks.task: Conducting agricultural research on reduced tillage systems for organic vegetable production. Under this, I can think of several subtasks:
subtasks: Seed cover crops.
Apply mechanical termination using a roller crimper.
Subdivide whole plot treatments for nitrogen management.
Monitor nitrate leaching.
Compare yields between treatments.

tasks.task: Evaluating cover crop termination methods. Subtasks would include:
subtasks: Using a specific roller crimper model.
Modifying equipment for better cover crop residue management.

tasks.task: Implementing no-till and strip-till for weed control. For strip-till, they had to use a prescriptive strip tiller, which has its own subtasks.
subtasks: SUBTASKS involved in using the strip tiller like row cleaning, cutting residue with a coulter, subsoiling with shanks, placing fertilizer, and breaking up clods. The video talks about each component of the Hineker 6000 strip tiller. Let me list those: row cleaners to move mulch, coulter to cut residue, subsoil shank with rolling discs, side-dressing unit for fertilizer, and a rolling basket. So each of these would be subtasks. So:
SUBTASK: Utilizing strip tiller for row cleaning.
Maintaining mulch layer in no-till plots.
Monitoring and controlling weeds outside the planting rows without mechanical tillage.
Apply pre-plant nitrogen fertilizer.
Applying granular nitrogen fertilizer at planting (full rate where needed and partial applied in pre-plant for the other subplot).
Setting up and applying the liquid fish product via fertigation in multiple events (starting 3 weeks after planting).

tasks.task: Conducting agricultural research on reduced tillage systems for organic vegetable production
Evaluating cover crop termination methods
Implementing strip-till for weed control and fertilizer application
Managing no-till plots for weed control and mulch maintenance.
Nitrogen Management (application and fertigation)
Conducting agricultural research. It's the overall research project that includes these tasks.
Conducting agricultural research on reduced tillage systems for organic vegetable production
Implementing cover crop termination methods using mechanical means.
Applying strip-till for weed control and fertilizer application.
Managing weed control in no-till organic broccoli and pepper plots.

But given the time constraints and the need to give tasks based on the transcript, and considering all the subtasks and their connection to the main research, perhaps the primary MAINTASK is the research project itself, with the subtasks as above.

But the transcript doesn't go into too much detail about the actual planting and harvesting. Instead, it's more about the methods and research processes. Therefore, while these processes are part of this MAINTASK, maybe not detailed enough to dive into subtasks related to planting and harvesting.
Conducting experiments on reduced tillage methods for organic vegetable production.
Conducting research on reduced tillage in organic production
Implementing cover crop and no-till practices
Using strip-till for alternative weed control and fertilization
Managing nitrogen applications and fertigation
Conducting research on reduced tillage in organic vegetables (covers multiple subtasks)
Alternatively, since the user might want more separated lists, but I think one MAINTASK for the research project and the grading system splits the different practices into subtasks under it.
Conducting agricultural research on reduced tillage systems for organic vegetable production
subtasks: Seed rye and vetch cover crops in the fall
Apply mechanical termination using a roller crimper when the cover crops are flowering
Subdivide plots into two subplots for nitrogen fertilization strategies
Apply full or partial rate nitrogen fertilizer (using granular chicken manure and liquid fish product via fertigation)
Monitor nitrate leaching using lysimeters
Compare crop yields between no-till, strip-till, and conventional till plots

tasks.task: Implementing cover crop and no-till practices
subtasks: Use a roller crimper (INJ model) to terminate cover crops
Maintain mulch layer in no-till plots
Control weeds in inter-row areas where mulch remains

tasks.task: Using strip-till for weed control and fertilizer application
subtasks: Utilize a strip tiller with row cleaners
Cut remaining cover crop residue with a coulter
Subsoil with rolling discs
Apply fertilizer via a side-dressing unit
Break up soil clods with a rolling basket
